name: Web Interface for Reflectivity Fitting
description:
This Django application provides a web interface to perform modeling of reflectivity data on remote computing nodes.
Alternatively, the generated Python script can also be executed locally, provided that sufficient computing resources and necessary third party libraries are installed.
description_good_justification: his application provides a user interface to generate a REFL1D script and run it on a remote node.
interact_justification:
To report a problem, please create an issue using the "Issues" tab above. 
If you would like to suggest changes, please either create an issue or a pull request (Gitlab).
contribution_justification:
The issue tracking system is based on the standard workflow of Gitlab. More details can be found in the link below:
https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/issues/managing_issues.html#:~:text=GitLab%20Issues%20are%20the%20fundamental%20medium%20for%20collaborating,you%20can%20use%20quick%20actions%20to%20enter%20them.

documentation_basics_justification:
The basic usage can be found in the linked document below:
https://code.ornl.gov/reflectometry/web_reflectivity/-/blob/next/README.md
documentation_interface_justification:
This application is a front web UI for post-processing of reflectivity data analysis.
It is not intended to be used by other applications, therefore no API is necessary for this web application.

name: CVE Binary Tool (cve-bin-tool)
description: This tool helps you find known vulnerabilities in your supply chain/dependencies.  It can take a known component list in several formats (including SBOM) or includes a binary scanner to discover a number of common, vulnerable components (including openssl, libpng, libxml2, expat)..

crypto_pfs_justification: We don't do any key management directly.
crypto_password_storage_justification: No passwords.  We may want to revisit this item when we add NVD API key support.

No direct use of the random number generator.  Places randomness is used:
- SSL communication uses Requests & urllib2
- Temporary file creation (during downloads) uses TempFile

name: beagle-android
description:
Beagle is an open-source framework for cross-platform development using the concept of Server-Driven UI.

This framework allows teams to build and alter layouts and data directly through a backend but yet display its contents natively in a mobile application and/or through the web.

It is also possible to create, test, and update native application components and screen paths without the need to update the mobile application at the store (App Store or Play Store).
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/ZupIT/beagle-android/blob/main/LICENSE.txt>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).

name: EVerest
description: The primary goal of EVerest is to develop and maintain an open source software stack for EV charging infrastructure. EVerest is developed having modularity and customizability in mind, so it consists of a framework to configure several interchangeable modules which are coupled by MQTT with each other. EVerest will help to speed the adoption to e-mobility by utilizing all the open source advantages for the EV charging world. It will also enable new features for local energy management, PV-integration, and many more.

name: beagle-web-react
description:
Beagle is an open source framework that helps developers implement Server-Driven UI in a cross-platform way.

By using Beagle, developers can:

Rapidly change an application layout, data, navigation flow, or even logic, just by changing code in the backend.
Be more independent of mobile stores, like App Store and Play Store, because most changes won’t need an app update.
Have more confidence that applications will behave similarly on different platforms, since code will be shared and standardized between backend and frontend.
Easily test new business hypothesis or make live fixes on applications to improve users' experience and receive feedback.

name: beagle-web-core
description:
Beagle is an open source framework that helps developers implement Server-Driven UI in a cross-platform way.

By using Beagle, developers can:

Rapidly change an application layout, data, navigation flow, or even logic, just by changing code in the backend. Be more independent of mobile stores, like App Store and Play Store, because most changes won’t need an app update. Have more confidence that applications will behave similarly on different platforms, since code will be shared and standardized between backend and frontend. Easily test new business hypothesis or make live fixes on applications to improve users' experience and receive feedback.

crypto_published_justification: Nothing is encrypted apart from password

name: KubeArmor
description: Cloud-native Runtime Security Enforcement System
contribution_requirements_justification:
https://github.com/kubearmor/KubeArmor/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md

This URL not only explains how the contributions should be made but also explains what forms of contributions are accepted. The coding standards and other procedures are mandated as part of GH actions.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/kubearmor/KubeArmor/blob/main/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).

repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification:
https://github.com/kubearmor/KubeArmor/issues/590

We have handled branching and release version strategy based on the issue mentioned above.
Essentially, we have 
main as our bleeding edge branch where things might be unstable. Release kubearmor every month or two with a new release version and release logs ... the versioning will be v0.2, v0.3 and so on ... If there are any backports, those will be handled as part of release-candidates version .. for e.g. v0.2-rc1, v0.2-rc2 and so on.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
main is the latest bleeding edge version.
v0.2, v0.3 are released versions.
We also maintain release candidates.
We have a formal flow enforced by GH actions for release management.
report_process_justification:
https://github.com/kubearmor/KubeArmor/issues/new/choose

Formal templates to submit bug/feature requests
report_responses_justification:
https://github.com/kubearmor/KubeArmor/issues

The community contributors manage the acks for the issues reported.
report_archive_justification:
All the information is kept on GH issues/PRs/wiki.
https://github.com/kubearmor/KubeArmor/issues
build_justification: We have automated release management process which is triggered on GH actions when a new branch or tag is created.
build_common_tools_justification: Any third party can recreate the releases. All the tools that we use are in public domain.
build_floss_tools_justification: We integrate with only FLOSS tools.
test_justification:
https://github.com/kubearmor/KubeArmor/tree/main/tests

We have following:
1. automated test suites
2. test suites triggered on PRs and pushes to branches.
3. CI fails if the test suites execution fails and PRs wont be merged.
test_most_justification: The test suites are invoked for main as well as version branches using GH actions.
warnings_justification: KubeArmor uses golangci-lint/gosec/go-fmt for enforcing lint/sec/indentation related guidelines.
warnings_fixed_justification: All the new warnings have to be handled. The old warnings from base code is left as it is.
warnings_strict_justification: All the new warnings have to be handled. The old warnings from base code is left as it is.
know_secure_design_justification: KubeArmor has a maintainer (@nyrahul) who has dealt with development/deployment related cyber security issues before. @nyrahul (github ID) has done threat modeling of kubearmor (blog: https://medium.com/@nyrahul/kubernetes-threat-modeling-bf044745cf85).
know_common_errors_justification: KubeArmor has a maintainer (@nyrahul) who has dealt with development/deployment related cyber security issues before. @nyrahul (github ID) has done threat modeling of kubearmor (blog: https://medium.com/@nyrahul/kubernetes-threat-modeling-bf044745cf85).
crypto_published_justification: We only use best practices as mentioned in NIST guidelines.
crypto_call_justification: KubeArmor does not implement any cryptographic functions itself. It relies on existing open sources such as libssl for such needs.
crypto_floss_justification: KubeArmor does not implement any cryptographic functions itself. It relies on existing open sources such as libssl for such needs.
crypto_keylength_justification: We only use best practices as mentioned in NIST guidelines.
crypto_working_justification: We only use best practices as mentioned in NIST guidelines.
crypto_pfs_justification: There are no dependency on authn algorithms in kubearmor. We only use best practices as mentioned in NIST guidelines.
crypto_password_storage_justification: Kubearmor does not maintain any secrets.
crypto_random_justification: There are no dependency on authn algorithms in kubearmor. We only use best practices as mentioned in NIST guidelines.
delivery_mitm_justification: KubeArmor is a application runtime security engine. It does not control any specific network/transport protocols to be used by the users. Internally for its own needs kubearmor uses GRPC with TLS for all connections needs.
delivery_unsigned_justification: KubeArmor is a application runtime security engine. It does not control any specific network/transport protocols to be used by the users. Internally for its own needs kubearmor uses GRPC with TLS for all connections needs.
static_analysis_justification:
Kubearmor uses following:
1. synk 
2. golangci-lint
3. gosec

tools for static code analysis.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Kubearmor uses synk which includes rules or approaches to look for common vulnerabilities in the analyzed language or environment
static_analysis_often_justification: Static source code analysis is automated in CI using GH actions and are triggered on every PR updates/commit push in the branch.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: We only use best practices as mentioned in NIST guidelines.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: CI is based on GH actions and are integral part of the dev process.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: KubeArmor and accessory repos do not keep any secrets in the public repos.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: @vaccinesignup
description: Notify LA-County users about available vaccine appointments.
description_good_justification: This Twitter bot notifies LA County users who DM their zip codes to @vaccinesignup about available vaccine-appointment Locations in their area.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup/blob/main/LICENSE>.
floss_license_osi_justification: // Did not find license in the OSI list.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
report_process_justification: Users can file bug reports via [GitHub Issues](https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup/issues/new/choose).
tests_documented_added_justification: This is documented in the pull-request template.
warnings_strict_justification: This project is in Ruby and so requires no compilation.
static_analysis_justification: CI integrates Code Climate, Coveralls, Dependabot, and RuboCop.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Any untrusted (non zip-code) input is discarded and automated testing, moreover, covers some edge cases.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Instead of embedding run-time assertions, there are many external tests with assertions that are checked during automated testing.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardening_justification: This project is a strict wrapper of the Twitter-client gem; hardened response headers are up to the library to apply. Since it isn't compiled, compiler flags don't appy. We believe the scope for attack is limited to direct-message input from Twitter and vulnerabilities in dependencies and Ruby itself. We mitigate the former's risk by discarding any untrusted input, while we address the latter risks by using Dependabot to patch known vulnerabilities automatically.
hardened_site_justification: GitHub [hosts the source](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/google_maps_geocoder/).
installation_common_justification: Users can uninstall by reversing the installation instructions and using `gem uninstall` on the gems from the `Gemfile`.
build_reproducible_justification: This project is written in Ruby and so does not require compilation.
dco_justification: The [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) specify a DCO, while the [PR template](https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup/blob/main/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md) includes the signed-off-by line.
code_of_conduct_justification: The project has adopted the [Ruby Community Conduct Guideline](https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md).
documentation_current_justification: Complete RDoc documentation is available inline in the source.
documentation_achievements_justification: The [README](https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup#vaccinesignup) displays continuous-integration badges, including the best-practices badge.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: As a Twitter bot, this project is fundamentally text-based and so is fairly accessible as-is.
internationalization_justification: As a wrapper for the Twitter gem, which doesn't currently support internationalization, this project can't easily support localization. Notwithstanding these technical constraints, the project's output primarily consists of proper nouns—pharmacy or clinic names and street addresses—limiting the utility of translations.
maintenance_or_update_justification: Only the bot's latest release is live.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: All vulnerabilities have so far been [reported by Dependabot](https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aclosed+author%3Aapp%2Fdependabot).
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: Dependabot automatically addresses known vulnerabilities. Users can also [report ones they find](https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup/issues/new/choose).
coding_standards_justification: CI [runs rubocop](https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup/blob/main/.github/workflows/test.yml#L33) which enforces standard Ruby style.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: CI [runs rubocop](https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup/blob/main/.github/workflows/test.yml#L33) which enforces standard Ruby style.
build_preserve_debug_justification: No build/installation system involving compilation is used since the project is written in Ruby.
build_non_recursive_justification: No build/installation system involving compilation is used since the project is written in Ruby.
build_repeatable_justification: No build/installation system involving compilation is used since the project is written in Ruby.
installation_development_quick_justifica: This project notes required environment variables in the README and CI runs standard RSpec for testing.
external_dependencies_justification: All dependencies are maintained by Bundler in [`Gemfile`](https://github.com/FoveaCentral/vaccinesignup/blob/main/Gemfile).
dependency_monitoring_justification: Dependabot automatically patches known vulnerabilities by opening pull requests which are promptly merged.
updateable_reused_components_justificati:
1. All dependencies are listed in the gemspec and maintained by Bundler.
2. Dependabot automatically patches known vulnerabilities by opening pull requests which are promptly merged.
interfaces_current_justification: CI calls rubocop, which identifies deprecated/obsolete functions as failures.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: CI invokes RSpec as a GitHub Action and displays results as a badge in the README.
regression_tests_added50_justification: No programmatic bugs (as opposed to CI) have been reported in the last six months, but adding regression tests is SOP anyway.
test_policy_mandated_justification: This is documented in the contributing guidelines.
implement_secure_design_justification: Because Twitter requires an API key, the library will fail by default since there is no default key.
input_validation_justification: Any user input is validated as zip codes and any non-matching content is discarded.
signed_releases_justification: The project is a Twitter bot whose code is not intended for widespread use.
copyright_per_file_justification: All original source files include the copyright notice.
license_per_file_justification: All original source files include the license notice.
require_2FA_justification: We require two-factor authentication for all organization members and outside collaborators as described in [Requiring two-factor authentication in your organization](https://docs.github.com/en/organizations/keeping-your-organization-secure/requiring-two-factor-authentication-in-your-organization).
test_branch_coverage80_justification: There are no top-to-bottom FLOSS tools available in Ruby which can measure branch coverage. Ruby version 2.5 was the first version that enabled capturing branch coverage, and it was only released on 2017-12-25. Other tools on top of Ruby need to be modified so that they can use this information.
